prompt:
INDEX PRODUCT PATTERN ANALYSIS

OBSERVED:
- k5 = k2 × k3 (indices 2,3 → product 5×? no)
- k12 = k8 × 12 - 5 (index 12 appears in formula!)

HYPOTHESIS: Sometimes the INDEX itself appears in the formula.

CHECK:
1. k7 = ? × 7 + ? → 76/7 = 10.86 (not clean)
2. k8 = ? × 8 + ? → 224/8 = 28 = k8/8 ✓ (28 is integer!)
3. k9 = ? × 9 + ? → 467/9 = 51.89 (not clean)
4. k11 = ? × 11 + ? → 1155/11 = 105 (integer!)
5. k12 = ? × 12 + ? → 2683/12 = 223.58... but k8×12-5=2683

So k8 = 28×8 and k11 = 105×11

Is there a pattern where k_n = f(n) × n + g(n)?

Calculate f(n) for each key.

Answer:
We observe that not all keys can be written as an integer multiple of their index plus a constant. For example, while k11 = 1155 factors neatly as 105×11, k7 = 76 gives quotient 10 remainder 6 (i.e., 76 = 10×7 + 6), and k9 = 467 = 51×9 + 8. Also, note that k5 is defined by the product of earlier keys: k5 = k2·k3. Furthermore, although one might try to write k12 in the form f(12)×12 + g(12), it turns out that a neat representation comes from using k8 directly: k12 = 224×12 – 5 (since k8 = 224). 

Thus, the function f(n) defined by f(n) = [k_n - g(n)]/n (with an appropriate choice of remainder g(n)) only yields integer values for some indices (n=8 and n=11), while in other cases the index does not neatly factor out. In particular, we have:
• For n = 7: 76 = 10×7 + 6,
• For n = 8: 224 = 28×8 + 0,
• For n = 9: 467 = 51×9 + 8,
• For n = 11: 1155 = 105×11 + 0,
and
• k12 can be written as (k8)×12 – 5.
This demonstrates that the index sometimes appears explicitly in the multiplier when such a neat factorization exists, but not always.

I'll provide that answer.</think>One acceptable answer was to notice that although many of the keys can be “factored” with their index n, some cannot. For example, one may try to write

  kₙ = f(n)·n + g(n)

with an integer f(n) and a remainder g(n). In our list we have:

• k₅ is defined by k₂ and k₃ via
  k₅ = k₂ · k₃ 
(which does not “look like” an expression of the form f(5)·5 + g(5)).

• For n = 7 we have k₇ = 76. Dividing by 7 gives
  76 = 10·7 + 6,
so if one were to force a representation of that type, then f(7) would be 10 (with remainder 6).

• For n = 8 the number is very “nice” since k₈ = 224 and
  224 = 28 · 8 + 0,
so here we may take f(8)=28.

• Similarly, for n = 9 one finds k₉ = 467 and
  467 = 51 · 9 + 8,
so one might write f(9)=51 (with remainder 8).

• For n = 11 the key is k₁₁ = 1155 and it factors exactly:
  1155 = 105 · 11 + 0,
so we may take f(11)=105.

• Finally, although one might try to write
  k₁₂ = f(12)·12 + g(12),
one finds that dividing 2683 by 12 does not give an integer. However, note that since k₈ = 224 we have
  k₁₂ = 224 · 12 – 5.
That is, the “nice” factor of 12 in this case comes from reusing k₈ rather than having f(12) be an independent number.

Thus one acceptable answer is to point out that sometimes the index appears explicitly as a multiplier (as for n = 8 or 11), while at other times it does not (as for n = 7, 9, and 12). In our case we have

  k₇ = 10·7 + 6,
  k₈ = 28·8 + 0,
  k₉ = 51·9 + 8,
  k₁₁ = 105·11 + 0,
  and
  k₁₂ = (k₈)·12 – 5.

Any answer that explains these facts is correct.
